location: A tent in the French camp. LEAR on a bed asleep,

lines.text: Enter CORDELIA, KENT, and Doctor

lines.speaker: cordelia
lines.text: O thou good Kent, how shall I live and work, To match thy goodness? My life will be too short, And every measure fail me.

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: To be acknowledged, madam, is o'erpaid. All my reports go with the modest truth; Nor more nor clipp'd, but so.

lines.speaker: cordelia
lines.text: Be better suited: These weeds are memories of those worser hours: I prithee, put them off.

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: Pardon me, dear madam; Yet to be known shortens my made intent: My boon I make it, that you know me not Till time and I think meet.

lines.speaker: cordelia
lines.text: Then be't so, my good lord. How does the king?
To the Doctor

lines.speaker: doctor
lines.text: Madam, sleeps still.

lines.speaker: cordelia
lines.text: O you kind gods, Cure this great breach in his abused nature! The untuned and jarring senses, O, wind up Of this child-changed father!

lines.speaker: doctor
lines.text: So please your majesty That we may wake the king: he hath slept long.

lines.speaker: cordelia
lines.text: Be govern'd by your knowledge, and proceed I' the sway of your own will. Is he array'd?

lines.speaker: gentleman
lines.text: Ay, madam; in the heaviness of his sleep We put fresh garments on him.

lines.speaker: doctor
lines.text: Be by, good madam, when we do awake him; I doubt not of his temperance.

lines.speaker: cordelia
lines.text: Very well.

lines.speaker: doctor
lines.text: Please you, draw near. Louder the music there!

lines.speaker: cordelia
lines.text: O my dear father! Restoration hang Thy medicine on my lips; and let this kiss Repair those violent harms that my two sisters Have in thy reverence made!

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: Kind and dear princess!

lines.speaker: cordelia
lines.text: Had you not been their father, these white flakes Had challenged pity of them. Was this a face To be opposed against the warring winds? To stand against the deep dread-bolted thunder? In the most terrible and nimble stroke Of quick, cross lightning? to watch--poor perdu!-- With this thin helm? Mine enemy's dog, Though he had bit me, should have stood that night Against my fire; and wast thou fain, poor father, To hovel thee with swine, and rogues forlorn, In short and musty straw? Alack, alack! 'Tis wonder that thy life and wits at once Had not concluded all. He wakes; speak to him.

lines.speaker: doctor
lines.text: Madam, do you; 'tis fittest.

lines.speaker: cordelia
lines.text: How does my royal lord? How fares your majesty?

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: You do me wrong to take me out o' the grave: Thou art a soul in bliss; but I am bound Upon a wheel of fire, that mine own tears Do scald like moulten lead.

lines.speaker: cordelia
lines.text: Sir, do you know me?

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: You are a spirit, I know: when did you die?

lines.speaker: cordelia
lines.text: Still, still, far wide!

lines.speaker: doctor
lines.text: He's scarce awake: let him alone awhile.

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: Where have I been? Where am I? Fair daylight? I am mightily abused. I should e'en die with pity, To see another thus. I know not what to say. I will not swear these are my hands: let's see; I feel this pin prick. Would I were assured Of my condition!

lines.speaker: cordelia
lines.text: O, look upon me, sir, And hold your hands in benediction o'er me: No, sir, you must not kneel.

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: Pray, do not mock me: I am a very foolish fond old man, Fourscore and upward, not an hour more nor less; And, to deal plainly, I fear I am not in my perfect mind. Methinks I should know you, and know this man; Yet I am doubtful for I am mainly ignorant What place this is; and all the skill I have Remembers not these garments; nor I know not Where I did lodge last night. Do not laugh at me; For, as I am a man, I think this lady To be my child Cordelia.

lines.speaker: cordelia
lines.text: And so I am, I am.

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: Be your tears wet? yes, 'faith. I pray, weep not: If you have poison for me, I will drink it. I know you do not love me; for your sisters Have, as I do remember, done me wrong: You have some cause, they have not.

lines.speaker: cordelia
lines.text: No cause, no cause.

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: Am I in France?

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: In your own kingdom, sir.

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: Do not abuse me.

lines.speaker: doctor
lines.text: Be comforted, good madam: the great rage, You see, is kill'd in him: and yet it is danger To make him even o'er the time he has lost. Desire him to go in; trouble him no more Till further settling.

lines.speaker: cordelia
lines.text: Will't please your highness walk?

lines.speaker: king lear
lines.text: You must bear with me: Pray you now, forget and forgive: I am old and foolish.
Exeunt all but KENT and Gentleman

lines.speaker: gentleman
lines.text: Holds it true, sir, that the Duke of Cornwall was so slain?

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: Most certain, sir.

lines.speaker: gentleman
lines.text: Who is conductor of his people?

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: As 'tis said, the bastard son of Gloucester.

lines.speaker: gentleman
lines.text: They say Edgar, his banished son, is with the Earl of Kent in Germany.

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: Report is changeable. 'Tis time to look about; the powers of the kingdom approach apace.

lines.speaker: gentleman
lines.text: The arbitrement is like to be bloody. Fare you well, sir.
Exit

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: My point and period will be throughly wrought, Or well or ill, as this day's battle's fought.
Exit
